Textiles by Anni Albers Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue at 92nd Street; (212) 423-3200.

An exhibition of textiles by Anni Albers (1899-1994) opens Sunday and runs through Aug. 20. The artist was a member of the Bauhaus School for 10 years before she and her husband, Josef Albers, immigrated to the United States in 1933. She was one of the first artists to make textiles intended to stand on their own as abstract artworks.

The central feature of the exhibition is made up of 25 large wall hangings. Dozens of smaller works are on display, including drapery and upholstery fabrics, swatches, weavings, jewelry, drawings and prints. The artist's textiles are known for abstract, geometric designs, made with threads like hemp and harness thread, and emphasizing the texture, shape and feel of the fibers. Open Sunday through Thursday, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. (Tuesday until 8 p.m.). Admission: $8; students and those 65 and older, $5.50; members, free.
Craft Times Four American Craft Museum, 40 West 53rd Street; (212) 956-3535.

Exhibitions by four artists will open on Wednesday and continue through Sept. 3. Fifty sculptures -- gazebos, benches, fountains, flowers and trees -- will be used to create a 30-by-40-foot garden inside the museum. In the garden, which is by Tommy Simpson, the Pilobolus Dance Company will perform from Wednesday through June 4, at 1 p.m. each day; on Wednesday and on June 2 at 5:30 and 7 p.m.; on June 1 at 5:30; and on June 3 and 4 at 2:30 and 4. Reservations required. No charge with museum admission.

Among the other exhibitions are a collection of 20 textiles by Judy Chicago, who uses techniques like embroidery, beading, needlepoint and painting on fabric to explore the meanings behind sayings like ''A Stitch in Time Saves Nine,'' ''Turn Over a New Leaf'' and ''Home Sweet Home.''

In the three-story atrium of the museum, Sandy Skoglund, a photographer and a glass artist, will install more than 2,000 glass dragonflies, which will vibrate as if in flight. Acrylic and polyester jewelry by Peter Chang will be shown, along with sculptures and decorative objects. Open Tuesday through Sunday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 8 p.m. on Thursday). Admission is $5; students and those 65 and older, $2.50; members and those younger than 12, free.

On Wednesday at 6 p.m., a preview party for ''Sculpture, Objects and Functional Art,'' known as SOFA New York, a show and sale of works at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 66th Street, will benefit the museum. Advance tickets start at $125; at the door, $200.
Talks by Designers Cantor Center, New York University, 36 East Eighth Street; (212) 998-7130.

Interior designers and architects, including Bunny Williams, Samuel G. White and Ralph Harvard, will give illustrated lectures about their work in a series on June 1, 8, 15 and 22. Lectures are at 6 p.m. Reservations are required, under Course No. XO4.9210. Fee, $170.
Garden Evenings Wave Hill, Independence Avenue and West 249th Street, Riverdale, the Bronx; (718) 549-3200.

Wave Hill, usually open Tuesday through Sunday from 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., will stay open until sunset every Wednesday through Aug. 30 for summertime programs. Dance performances will be offered in July; on other Wednesdays, there will be music performances and garden walks and talks.

Topics in the garden programs, which will be from 6:15 to 7:30 p.m., will include trees for the home garden on Wednesday, garden design on June 7, basic pruning on June 28 and vines and vertical plants on Aug. 9. No charge with grounds admission of $4; students and those over 62, $2; members and those under 6, free.
''Welcome,'' an exhibition exploring the relationship of people and nature using furniture, wall coverings and decorative objects, will be at Wave Hill through Aug. 20.
Art and Antiques Neuberger Museum of Art; (914) 251-6115.

Five houses in Westchester will be on a self-guided tour on June 5 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. One is a 10,000-square-foot Modernist house designed in 1935 by Edward Durrell Stone, with much of its original furniture; one has a pond, a waterfall and hundreds of azaleas, rhododendrons and wildflowers; a third has artworks by Richard Serra, Deborah Butterfield and Magritte. Reservations required. Tickets, $90; members, $75.
Dutchess County Tour Stissing House, at Routes 82 and 199; (914) 471-1630.
Six historic properties, including an 1814 clapboard building and the Evergreen Cemetery, established in 1820, will be on a self-guided tour on June 3 from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tickets, $25.
